div.p: This paper addresses the problem of cluster formation control for a networked multi-agent system in the simultaneous presence of aperiodic sampling and communication delays. First, to fulfil multiple formation tasks, a group of agents are decomposed into M distinct and nonoverlapping clusters. The agents in each cluster are then driven to achieve a desired formation while the multi-agent system as a whole accomplishes M cluster formations. Second, by a proper modeling of aperiodic sampling and communication delays, an aperiodic sampled-data cluster formation protocol is delicately constructed such that the information exchanges among neighboring agents only occur intermittently at discrete instants of time. Third, a detailed theoretical analysis of cluster formability is carried out and a sufficient and necessary condition is provided such that the system is M -cluster formable. Furthermore, a discontinuous Lyapunov functional approach is developed to derive a design criterion on the existence of an admissible sampled-data cluster formation protocol. Finally, numerical simulations on a team of nonholonomic mobile robots are given to illustrate the effectiveness of the obtained theoretical result.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: F ORMATION control, as one of the most fundamental distributed cooperative control problems for multi-agent systems (MASs), has attracted considerable interest from control and robotics communities in recent years. Applications of multi-agent formation control cover a broad range of areas, such as search and rescue operations [1], satellite and spacecraft formation flying [2], source seeking and exploration [3], [4]. Generally, the objective of formation control is to drive a group of autonomous agents to achieve and to maintain a desired geometric structure or pattern on their states or outputs [5]. Up until now, significant research efforts have been devoted to addressing formation control of various MASs, including unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) [6]- [8], autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) [9], [10], nonholonomic mobile robots [3], [5], [11]- [16], first-order integrators [17], [18], second-order integrators [19]- [23] and higher-order dynamics [24], [25]. Note that different agent dynamics and formation tasks call for different formation control strategies. Representative approaches for multi-agent formation control in the literature can be arguably categorized as behaviorbased approaches [13], virtual structure approaches [7], [10], [16], leader-following approaches [9], [11], [12], [14], [22], graph theory-based approaches [6], [18], [19] and consensus approaches [3], [8], [15], [17], [20], [21], [23]- [25].

Although several formation protocols and algorithms for MASs have been designed in the literature, it is worth mentioning that most aforementioned results are developed to solve a single formation control problem, where all the agents therein are driven to form one single geometric pattern. However, such a single formation case may be unrealistic or even fail to perform multiple distinct formation tasks in many practical circumstances. For example, consider the crime deterrence scenario by making multi-robot formations in a sense of security against invaders [26]. When there is more than one invader passing along a way in a surveillance area, a team of mobile robots should be first broken down into multiple groups and then different groups make various troop formations to capture or enclose the invaders. The other example is the search and rescue scenario by multiple robots in a disaster site, where victims are required to be located and rescued. In this case, a diverse group of robots with different capabilities should be deployed to develop various formations so as to efficiently find and aid the victims. Under these circumstances, it is impossible to employ a single-formation-based control strategy and the existing multi-agent formation protocols and algorithms cannot be applied to implement multiple formation missions.

Recently, inspired by the existing group/cluster consensus literature [27]- [31], the time-varying group formation control problem for a linear MAS was investigated in [25]. The agents therein were partitioned into multiple subgroups and multiple sub-formations were realized by the whole MAS. Sufficient conditions for group formation were derived and an algebraic Riccati equation based approach was presented to design the group formation protocol. Note that the formation protocol in [25] requires continual and instantaneous interagent communication, which means that each agent communicates with its neighboring ones at every instant of time and information sent by each agent is instantly delivered to its neighbors. Apparently, this requirement is not suitable within a networked communication environment. For example, in the wireless networked multi-quadrotor UAV system [23], each quadrotor's state (position and velocity) should be first sampled by digital measurement modules at discretized instants and then be sent to a ground control station through a wireless communication medium (e.g., the Zigbee network). In this situation, conventional formation control protocols based on continual inter-agent communication are no longer applicable on account of sampled and digital measurement. Besides, practical communication networks may suffer from limited network bandwidth and/or congested network traffic, thus rendering delayed or lost information exchange among the agents. For example, in underwater vehicle navigation, the communication channel possesses low bit rates, delays and data losses [10]. These network-induced constraints (e.g., sampling, delays, data losses) may result in most of the aforementioned formation protocols suffering from limitations when applying to networked MASs. Hence, the following question naturally arises: Does there exist an admissible formation control protocol such that a networked MAS can simultaneously realize multiple distinct formations even under the effects of some network-induced constraints? To the best of the authors' knowledge, such a problem has not been addressed yet, which deserves an investigation. This motivates the present study.

In this paper, we will address the cluster formation control problem for an MAS operating via a communication network. A generalized M -cluster state formation framework will be considered such that the MAS evolves various predefined formations to suit for different distributed tasks. For this purpose, we will decompose a group of agents into M disjoint clusters, while the agents in each cluster will be required to reach a specific geometric formation. It will be shown that the developed M -cluster formation framework covers some existing single formation frameworks, group (or cluster) consensus frameworks and (leadless) consensus frameworks as its special cases. The major contribution is twofold. i) A delicate aperiodic sampled-data cluster formation protocol will be proposed under which the information exchanges among neighboring agents only take place intermittently at discrete and aperiodic sampling instants. Communication delays among the agents will also be taken into account; and ii) A sufficient and necessary condition which guarantees the M -cluster formability of the MAS will be derived and a numerically efficient criterion for designing the desired cluster formation protocol will also be presented.

div.head: B. Non-Overlapping Decomposition
div.p: Different from the existing formation control problems where all the agents are governed to form a single geometric pattern [7], [8], [10]- [12], [14]- [19], [21]- [24], in the following, we will consider a cluster formation problem. To achieve this goal, the N agents in (1) will be firstly split into several clusters such that the whole MAS will achieve various predefined geometric formations. In doing so, the following definition is presented.
Definition 1: Let V be an index set of N interacting nodes.

div.head: C. M -Cluster State Formation
div.p: A formation often represents a geometric structure or pattern which satisfies some prescribed inter-agent geometric constraints achieved and preserved by a group of agents. There are a variety of formation representations, such as distancebased formations [18], [22], displacement-based formations [32] and position-based formations [11]. In the sequel, we use the relative vectors between agents to describe the geometric formation pattern.
For any m ∈ M, the desired state formation of the agents in cluster V m is represented by the following augmented timeinvariant vector
div.formula: fm = col{f lm+1 , f lm+2 , • • • , f lm+nm } ∈ R nmnx where f p ∈ R nx , ∀ p ∈ V m ,
div.p: is the anticipated sub-formation vector for agent p. Let F = col{ f1 , f2 , • • • , fM } be the vector specifying the desired cluster state formation of all the N agents and xm (t) = col{x lm+1 (t), x lm+2 (t), • • • , x lm+nm (t)} be the augmented state vector of the agents in cluster V m . The definition of M -cluster state formation is given as follows.
Definition 3: (M -Cluster State Formation) MAS (1) achieves M -cluster state formation specified by F if there exists a vector-valued function r m (t) ∈ R nx such that
div.formula: lim t→∞ ( xm (t) -fm -rm (t) ) = 0 nmnx , ∀ m ∈ M (3)
div.p: holds for any given bounded initial condition, where rm (t) = 1 nm ⊗ r m (t) with r m (t) ∈ R nx representing a formation position vector in cluster V m to be determined later. Remark 3: Note that if (3) holds, then one has
div.formula: lim t→∞ (x p (t) -f p -r m (t)) = 0 nx (4)
div.p: for any p ∈ V m ; m ∈ M. Thus, x p (t) -f p eventually reaches a common value, which guarantees that the desired formation shape can be maintained. Moreover, an alternative representation of (3) can be given by
div.formula: lim t→∞ (x p (t) -x q (t)) = f p -f q , p, q ∈ V m (5)
div.p: for each cluster. This requires that the state difference between any two agents p and q in the same cluster asymptotically converges to the desired constant offset f p -f q , which defines the formation shape/frame, and thus the two patterns formed by x p (t) and f p for all the agents in the same cluster are congruent. In this sense, the desired formation in each cluster can be successfully achieved by the agents. It should be mentioned that r m (t) in ( 3) is defined to guide a group of agents to track an anticipated trajectory fm . Thus, r m (t) can be deemed as a position vector of the formation in cluster V m . Consequently, the control objective of M -cluster formation is to make all the agents in cluster V m reach an agreement on r m (t) while keeping the offset vector fm and the MAS as a whole reaches M cluster formations. On the other hand, from (5), if f p ≡ f q for any p, q ∈ V m , then one has lim t→∞ (x p (t) -x q (t)) = 0. In other words, all the n m agents in cluster V m achieve a point formation or reach a state consensus. In this case, the proposed M -cluster formation framework covers the existing cluster (or group) state consensus frameworks [27]- [31] as a special case. In particular, if there is only one cluster involved in MAS (1), then one has from (5) that lim t→∞
div.formula: (x i (t) -x j (t)) = f i -f j , ∀ i, j ∈ V.
div.p: On this occasion, the proposed M -cluster state formation framework reduces to the conventional single state formation frameworks [17], [19], [24]. Furthermore, if one enforces f i ≡ f j , ∀ i, j ∈ V, the well-studied state consensus frameworks [33], [34] can be retrieved. Hence, the proposed M -cluster formation framework is more general than some existing ones.

Remark 4: Assumption 1 reveals that the intra-cluster interactions represented by L mm in the same cluster are all cooperative and the inter-cluster interactions represented by L mn , m = n, among different clusters are either cooperative or antagonistic. This assumption is reasonable in practical situations because the agents in the same cluster should work cooperatively to achieve a desired formation, while the agents among different clusters can work either cooperatively or antagonistically only provided the MAS as a whole achieves various expected cluster formations. As a matter of fact, the particular case of L mn ≡ 0 nm×nn for any m = n implies that M clusters of agents are controlled independently to realize M various formations. However, it should be pointed out that the inter-cluster interactions highlight a distinct difference between the proposed M -cluster state formation and M independently controlled state formations. Allowing different clusters to be interacted enables one to perform multiple formation control more efficiently and effectively. For example, consider a disaster site where a team of robots is controlled to perform the search and rescue mission for survivors. If the framework of M independently controlled formations is adopted, M clusters of robots can be controlled independently by M distant control stations. Due to lack of inter-cluster interactions, it is quite possible that two clusters of robots finally locate the same victim while leaving another victim without being detected and treated timely.

The receiver on each agent has the capability of gathering information from itself as well as its neighboring agents. div.head: V. APERIODIC SAMPLED-DATA CLUSTER FORMATION PROTOCOL DESIGN
div.p: In this section, we will focus on answering the question of under what condition there exists an admissible aperiodic sampled-data CFP (9) such that the M -cluster state formability of MAS (1) can be guaranteed. A sufficient criterion on the existence of such a CFP will be established.

Note that Theorem 1 provides a sufficient and necessary condition under which MAS ( 1) is M -cluster formable with regard to F . However, it does not show how to solve out the formation control gain K. Besides, it is generally difficult to directly apply Theorem 1 due to the fact that 1) the nonzero eigenvalues λ i , i = M + 1, M + 2, • • • , N , of the Laplacian matrix L may be complex, rendering the analysis and design much complicated; and 2) one needs to check the asymptotic stability of N -M subsystems, thereby increasing the computational complexity, especially when the scale of the MAS is large.

We are now in a position to present a simple and efficient criterion for designing an admissible sampled-data CFP of the form ( 9) such that the proposed sampled-data cluster formation control problem is solvable. For ease of exposition, we let λ1 = Re(λ M +1 )+jν, λ2 = Re(λ M +1 )-jν, λ3 = Re(λ N )+ jν and λ4 = Re(λ N ) -jν, where ν = max{Im(λ i )} for all i = M +1, M +2, • • • , N and j is the imaginary unit satisfying j 2 = -1.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSION
div.p: The cluster formation control problem of a networked MAS subject to aperiodic sampling and communication delays has been addressed. To fulfil different formation tasks, a group of agents have been decomposed into M non-overlapping clusters. The agents in different clusters have been driven to achieve distinct state formations, and thus the MAS as a whole has reached the desired M -cluster formation. Then, by a proper modeling of aperiodic sampling and communication delays among agents, an aperiodic sampled-data transmission scheme has been developed. Moreover, a sufficient and necessary condition on the cluster formability and a sufficient condition on the existence of an admissible sampled-data cluster formation protocol have been provided. An application to a team of nonholonomic mobile robots has been studied, through which the effectiveness of the proposed sampleddata distributed cluster formation control approach has been demonstrated through simulations.
